subject: Re: Testing Rules Changes

messageBody:
Rob Rambusch wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Paul Hodgetts <phodgetts@a...> wrote:
> [snip...]
> > Once you have unit tests for your rules, changing a rule's
> > behavior should have some effect on the tests. The assertions
> > that break tell you what the behavioral change was. If nothing
> > breaks, perhaps that says the test coverage is not sufficient,
> > or the rule change had no practical effect.Paul:
>
> Thank you for your comprehensive answer. Let's presume I've reached
> the stage where I have successfully implemented the rules engine along
> with a full suite of unit tests. Would I be violating any canons by
> having JUnit output its results in some text-like form to enable quick
> comparisons between result sets of different rules changes ? Is there
> a more elegant way to accomplish this ? I'm essentially trying to come
> up with a quick way to tell the user "When you change Rule # 5 that
> way, loans 1, 4 and 7 fail but 2,3 and 89 now pass.".

Whenever you run your unit tests, the test results are reported
back. Different runners report back the results in different
ways, from the GUI with the green bar [1], to XML results
generated by an Ant task [2]. So, yes, you have a number of
options for capturing the test results to report them back.
Depending on the format, you could use some sort of diff/compare
tool to point out differences between two results sets if you
need that, but within each run it would be obvious what works
and what breaks.

When you say "tell the user," who is the consumer of these test
results? I ask because, for the most part, JUnit results are a
bit programmer-oriented. You can of course take something like
XML results and format them nicer for non-programmer consumption,
or even write your own listener to output results as needed.
But the results generally report back assertions that fail and
stack traces and things like that.

If you are looking for some tests that someone like a Product
Manager might be able to work with, you might want to look into
something like the Fit [3] or Fitnesse [4] frameworks that allows
them to specify tests in a table-like format either in a Word/HTML
doc or on a wiki page. These are higher-level functional tests,
but your last line sounds to me a lot like a functional test, with
the "user" experimenting with the rules to see what loan types
break.

[1] http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookbook/cookbook.htm
[2] http://ant.apache.org/manual/OptionalTasks/junitreport.html
[3] http://fit.c2.com/
[4] http://www.fitnesse.org/

Hope that helps,
Paul
